card.name: PythagoraSwitch
card.desc:
Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus reaches Londin-dans-les-Montagnes, shows his unmistakable Horologium pendant to the town guards and is immediatelty escorted to the Queen of the Normans. As the confidential information in his possession suggested, her rank is revealed to be just a cerimonial façade: as a matter of fact, she holds no power. Nouveau Grande-Bretagne's form of government is something unconceivable for the rest of the Known World: a mix of hierocracy and technarchy, based on a peculiar, NeoPlatonic-tinged cult of Science and firmly steered by the clever authority of the seventy-fourth Evèque of Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, Remi डम्बर Kirwyn.
After a meticulous and rather embarassing strip-search and short and purely formal audience with the Queen, during which Severus does his best to state his motives as clearly (concerning intentions) and vaguely (concerning information) as possible, he is led to the upper floors of the many-bridged Sky Towers, where he finally meets the Evèque. The two discuss conditions and very restricted information; then consent to the terms of a historical exchange: Severus will submit the Hybernian Artifact and his liberty to the authority of the Evèque, and the Evèque will make him his personal assistant for the ultra-secret _Le Départ_ project, under the new name Pythagoras.



## Screwy Cogs (_Dark_)

**Question**: _How does project Le Départ relate to the Normans' belief system?_
**Stage**: _The Hall of the Evèque in the Sky Towers of Londin-dans-les-Montagnes_
**Characters**: _Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus, Remi डम्बर Kirwyn, seventy-fourth Evèque of Nouveau Grande-Bretagne._

**Answer**:

[Excerpt from the conversation between Remi डम्बर Kirwyn and Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus]

"I gather that the Queen was not a problem" Said the dark-skinned Remi, shrouded in his crimson robe.
"Not at all, Eminence. She seemed pleased with my patchy report." Answered Iulius.
"So young, yet so perfect for her role! She's the most impeccably brainless monarch in the last six or seven decades - brainlessness being of course the most important quality for a Norman Monarch besides regal appearance... and the main reason why so many of the last monarchs have been, in fact, monarch_esses_".
"Circumspectors in Rome have been knowing for long that your Queen was a purely cerimonial cover for your technochratic meddlings, but I think nobody, even in the Purpura Officium, ever suspected the extent of her uselessness."
"Your masters in Rome never suspected of many important matters as far as I know. Starting with your willingness to betray them."
"Throwing authorities off the scent is my most obvious skill. I didn't succeed with your men just because I didn't even try."
"Don't overestimate your gift for divertion, Iulius. But don't underestimate it, too. It's precisely for that gift that I arranged things to get you here, as you may have guessed."
"Your men have been quite explicit about that since the first fortuitous meeting we had in Sirmium. And about your interest in the Hybernian Artifact. But their clearness about your motives was frankly much less remarkable. You Normans have never been interested in extra-continuum technology: has something changed? And why me? I'm not silly enough to buy the flimflam you instructed them to throw at me. Yet I'm here: what do you really want of me? And what do you offer?"
"I'm sure you perfectly understand that you're currently in no position to negotiate. And I have no obligation to reward you. I could actually take your precious artifact and have you locked up in jail at any moment."
"But you're not doing that. Why?"
"Because, as I suggested before, I need your skills. Your knowledge of Roman technology, coupled with your dexterity with cover-ups and decit aimed at the Empire's enemies and rivals... and at the Empire itself. I'm offering you a position as my personal assistant. But I'm sure you want to know more about the matter you'll be assisting me with."
"My will doesn't seem to be of great importance, in this conversation."
"On the contrary! It's all about your will. I won't force you to accept my proposal. The sheer presence of the Hybernian Artifact in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne's territory is already a service great enough to guarantee you full protection, without any obligations apart from the commitment of never leaving the Sky Towers.
But let's get to business. First of all, I need you to know a bit about the background of the project I'm asking you to work on. That will be funnier if we proceed à rebours. What do you know about the Norman view of the Cosmos?"
"As we do, you trust that our world is a mechanism crafted by a Creator, a Magister Horologiorum. Like us, you got that conviction from the Greeks. But, contrarily to us, you don't believe that the Mechanism is perfect. Before reverting to the religion of our Fathers, we took the best from Aristotheles and the Bible. You followed the path of Epicurus and the Gnostics, and mixed their views with the heathen idea that one day the Sky will be falling on your head. You believe the Mechanism is faulty, and your priests' main task is to keep it ticking as it should."
"A good resumé, my compliments. Of course, you've missed the whole point of our worldview. But the ingredients are right. Let me correct your exposition: we don't believe that the Mechanism is faulty. We are sure it is. We have proofs. And you - both Romans, Parthians and Qin - would have them too, weren't you so blinded by your own religious dogmas. Let's talk about the Mantle. What is it? According to Qin, it's the black part of the Yin and Yang, with the moon in it playing the role of the small white dot. According to the Parthians... They estabilished as Truth that it is the shadow cast by Ahrimazd on the material world to make it tainted with Evil. And for you Romans... You actually never gave a damn, did you? As long as it doesn't prevent your Automatons saling the seas of the Known World, its nature is not your concern. But we know. And we have been knowing for centuries.
The Mantle is the most visible proof that our world is part of the Orrery. And that our Orrery is broken. It's a floating dome made of crystalline Aether, designed by the Horloger to block the light of the Sun. It used to move around the Earth one time per day, guaranteeing a balanced night-day cycle almost everywhere on Earth. But now it does not anymore, because the Rouages that spinned it are broken."
"But we do have night-day cycles! And Qin has got to the Moon just as we did, piercing through your "floating dome". Were it made of crystal, wouldn't it have crashed?"
"Aether crystal. It's immaterial, and it can be travelled through. Our best materiologists claim to be a few years away of creating a small specimen of it. As for night-day cycles... They are not uniform in the present time. In the lands of the Empire, day is consistently longer than night, and it gets longer and longer as you travel to the West. Due West from Hybernia there is the Torrid Zone, where the Sun never sets and the temperature is so high that your ships cannot travel safely - nor humans survive, as far as we know. Most of Qin's territory is always shrouded in the blackest night. And even here in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, we get just a small fraction of daylight, for a few moments a day. That's because of Libration: the wheels are jammed, and they keep on oscillating forward and backward instead of completing a full rotation as they should."
"I hope the role you have in mind for me doesn't envisage my full conversion to this worldview, Eminence."
"No it doesn't. But I must dig a bit deeper into it for you to unerstand the purpose of project Le Départ. I must tell you about the other Orreries."
"Other orreries? Isn't just one, ehr... inventive enough?"
"As for the rest of our model, we have proofs. Evidence. Extra-contextus artifacts, and old inscriptions buried in mountain caverns."
"Extra-contextus artifacts? I thought that you--"
"Had no interest in them? Of course. We don't need to plagiarize their technology as you and Qin do. We have ours. Why should we be satisfied with copycat science which will never take ourselves any farther than our Orrery's Moon, when we can design ships capable of travelling out of the Atmosphere, and taking us to other Orreries?
Centuries ago, when my people still inhabited the regions North of your Empire, our warriors found a very interesting artifact, and took it to our priests. It was a bronze model orrery. At first, they thougth it to be Greek. Then they noticed that the inscriptions on it were not in any known language, that the borders between territories weren't like the borders their world had ever had, and that the bronze dome guaranteeing night-day cycles perfectly rotated around the inner sphere. It was not our Orrery! But the priests didn't take the matter seriously, back in the day.
Then we moved to Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, and began exploring the neighbourhood. Reports from our envoyés came from all over our new small but gnarled kingdom. In a cavern, right under the mount the locals called Kangchenjunga, an enourmous cave was found, with many rooms and pits. And on the bottom of it, an inscription in the same character set as one found on the Other Orrery. 65336 letters from a 32-letter alphabet. Our Orrery's seed. _La Graine_.
We are part of an experiment, Iulius. We live in a miniature universe created by the Horloger for the same purpose that's been animating the Normans since their very first day in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne: science. We cannot know the mind of the Horloger, but we know that we are not alone: other miniature world exist too. Billions, and billions, and billions and billions of Orreries like ours. Probably the Horloger is interested in some statistics of sort. Probably he is running an extremely complex parallel simulation. You Romans have been mislead by your blind optimism: he's doesn't have much interest in our specific world. Our Orrery's just one among many more than we can possibly conceive. And it's broken. We've never been able to locate the other Orreries, but with your Hybernian Artifact we finally have a device capable of receiving - and possibly transmitting - signals from other Orreries. We have a Beacon which will guide us to an other Orrery! We must get away, Iulius, or the Sky will eventually fall on our heads!"

"Circumspectors in Rome have longly been knowing your Queen was a purely cerimonial cover for your technochratic meddlings, but I think nobody, even in Purpura Officium, ever suspected the extent of her uselessness."
"Your masters in Rome never suspected of many important matters as far as I know. Starting with your willingness to betray them."
"Throwing authorities off the scent is my most obvious skill. I didn't succeed with your men just because I didn't even try."
- Don't overestimate your gift for divertion, Iulius. But don't underestimate it, too. It's precisely for that gift that I arranged things to get you here, as you may have guessed.
"Your men have been quite explicit about that since the first fortuitous meeting we had in Sirmium. And about your interest in the Hybernian Artifact. But their clearness about your motives was frankly much less remarkable. You Normans have never been interested in extra-continuum technology: why starting now? And why trying to get to me? I'm not silly enough to buy the flimflam you instructed them to throw at me.  Yet I'm here: what do you really want of me? And what do you offer?"
"I'm sure you perfectly understand that you're currently in no position to negotiate. And I have no obligation to reward you. I could actually take your precious artifact and have you locked up in jail at any moment."
"But you're not doing that. Why?"
"Because, as I suggested before, I need your skills. Your knowledge of Roman technology, coupled with your dexterity with cover-ups and decit aimed at the Empire's enemies and rivals... and at the Empire itself. I'm offering you a position as my personal assistant. But I'm sure you want to know more about the matter you'll be assisting me with."
"My will doesn't seem to be much important, in this conversation.
- On the contrary! It's all about your will. I won't force you to accept my proposal. The sheer presence of the Hybernian Artifact in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne's territory is already a service great enough to guarantee you full protection, without any obligations apart from the commitment of never leaving the Sky Towers.
But let's get to business. First of all, I need you to know a bit about the background of the project I'm asking you to work on. That will be funnier if we proceed à rebours. What do you know about the Norman view of the Cosmos?"
"As we do, you trust that our world is a mechanism crafted by a Creator, a Magister Horologiorum. Like us, you got that conviction from the Greeks. But, contrarily to us, you don't believe that the Mechanism is perfect. Before reverting to the religion of our Fathers, we took the best from Aristotheles and the Bible. You followed the path of Epicurus and the Gnostics, and mixed their views with the heathen idea that one day the Sky will be falling on your head. You believe the Machanism is faulty, and your priests' main task is to keep it ticking as it should."
"A good resumé, my compliments. Of course, you've missed the whole point of our worldview. But the ingredients are right. Let me correct your exposition: we don't believe that the Mechanism is faulty. We are sure it is. We have proofs. And you - both Romans, Parthians and Qin - would have them too, weren't you so blinded by your own religious dogmas. Let's talk about the Mantle. What is it? According to Qin, it's the black part of the Yin and Yang, with the moon in it playing the role of the small white dot. According to the Parthians... They estabilished as Truth that it is the shadow cast by Ahrimazd on the material world to make it tainted with Evil. And for you Romans... You actually never gave a damn, did you? As long as it doesn't prevent your Automatons to sail the seas of the Known World, its nature is not your concern. But we know. And we have been knowing for centuries.
The Mantle is the most visible proof that our world is part of the Orrery. And that our Orrery is broken. It's a floating dome made of crystalline Aether, designed by the Horloger to block the light of the Sun. It used to move around the Earth one time per day, guaranteeing a balanced night-day cycle almost everywhere on Earth. But now it does not anymore, because the Rouages that spinned it are broken."
"But we do have night-day cycles! And Qin has got to the Moon just as we did, piercing through your "floating dome". Were it made of crystal, wouldn't it have crashed?"
"Aether crystal. It's immaterial, and it can be travelled through. Our best alchemists claim to be a few years away of creating a small specimen of it. As for night-day cycles... They are not uniform in the present time. In the lands of the Empire, day is consistently longer than night, and it gets longer and longer as you travel to the West. Due West from Hybernia there is the Torrid Zone, where the Sun never sets and the temperature is so high that your ships cannot travel safely - nor humans survive, as far as we know. Most of Qin's territory is always shrouded in the blackest night. And even here in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, we get just a small fraction of daylight, for a few moments a day. That's because of Libration: the wheels are jammed, and they keep on oscillating forward and backward instead of completing a full rotation as they should."
"I hope the role you have in mind for me doesn't envisage my full conversion to this worldview, Eminence."
"No it doesn't. But I must dig a bit deeper into it for you to unerstand the purpose of project Le Départ. I must tell you about the other Orreries."
"Other orreries? Isn't just one, ehr... inventive enough?"
"As for the rest of our model, we have proofs. Evidence. Extra-contextus artifacts, and old inscriptions buried in mountain caverns."
"Extra-contextus artifacts? I thought that you--"
"Had no interest in them? Of course. We don't need to plagiarize their technology as you and Qin do. We have ours. Why should we be satisfied with a technology which will never take ourselves any farther than our Orrery's Moon, when we can design ships capable of travelling out of the Atmosphere, and taking us to other Orreries?
But centuries ago, when my people still inhabited the regions North of your Empire, our warriors found a very interesting artifact, and took it to our priests. It was a bronze model orrery. At first, they thougth it to be Greek. Then they noticed that the inscriptions on it were not in any known language, that the borders between states weren't like the borders their world had ever had, and that the bronze dome guaranteeing night-day cycles perfectly rotated around the inner sphere. It was not our Orrery, but the priests didn't take the matter seriously, back in the day.
Then we moved to Nouveau Grande-Bretagne. We started exploring the neighbourhood. Reports from our envoyés stared coming from all over our new small but gnarled kingdom. In a cavern, right under the mount the locals called Kangchenjunga, an enourmous cave was found, with many rooms and pits. And on the bottom of it, an inscription in the same character set as one found on the Other Orrery. 65336 letters from a 32-letter alphabet. Our Orrery's seed. _La Graine_.
We are part of an experiment, Julius. We live in a miniature universe created by the Horloger for the same purpose that's been animating the Normans since their very first day in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne: science. We cannot know the mind of the Horloger, but we know that we are not alone: other miniature world exist too. Billions, and billions, and billions and billions of Orreries like ours. Probably the Horloger is interested in some statistics of sort. Probably he is running an extremely complex parallel simulation. You Romans have been mislead by your blind optimism: he's doesn't have much interest in us. Our Orrery's just one among many more than we can possibly conceive. And it's broken. We've never been able to locate the other Orreries, but with your Hybernian Artifact we finally have a device capable of receiving - and possibly transmitting - signals from other Orreries. We have a Beacon which will guide us to an other Orrery! We must get away, Iulius, or the Sky will eventually fall on our heads!"

old.desc:
Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus reaches Londin-dans-les-Montagnes, shows his unmistakable Horologium pendant to the town guards and is immediatelty escorted to the Queen of the Normans. As the confidential information in his possession suggested, her rank is revealed to be just a cerimonial façade: as a matter of fact, she holds no power. Nouveau Grande-Bretagne's form of government is something unconceivable for the rest of the Known World: a mix of hierocracy and technarchy, based on a peculiar, NeoPlatonic-tinged cult of Science and firmly steered by the clever authority of the seventy-fourth Evèque of Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, Remi डम्बर Kirwyn.
After a meticulous and rather embarassing strip-search and short and purely formal audience with the Queen, during which Severus does his best to state his motives as clearly (concerning intentions) and vaguely (concerning information) as possible, he is led to the upper floors of the many-bridged Sky Towers, where he finally meets the Evèque. The two discuss conditions and very restricted information; then consent to the terms of a historical exchange: Severus will submit the Hybernian Artifact and his liberty to the authority of the Evèque, and the Evèque will make him his personal assistant for the ultra-secret _Le Départ_ project, under the new name Pythagoras.

"Your men have been quite explicit about that since the first fortuitous meeting we had in Sirmium. And about your interest in the Hybernian Artifact. But their clearness about your motives was frankly much less remarkable. You Normans have never been interested in extra-continuum technology: why starting now? And why trying to get to me? I'm not silly enough to buy the flimflam you instructed them to throw at me.  Yet I'm here: what do you really want of me? And what do you offer?"
"I'm sure you perfectly understand that you're currently in no position to negotiate. And I have no obligation to reward you. I could actually take your precious artifact and have you locked up in jail at any moment."
"But you're not doing that. Why?"
"Because, as I suggested before, I need your skills. Your knowledge of Roman technology, coupled with your dexterity with cover-ups and decit aimed at the Empire's enemies and rivals... and at the Empire itself. I'm offering you a position as my personal assistant. But I'm sure you want to know more about the matter you'll be assisting me with."
"My will doesn't seem to be much important, in this conversation.
- On the contrary! It's all about your will. I won't force you to accept my proposal. The sheer presence of the Hybernian Artifact in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne's territory is already a service great enough to guarantee you full protection, without any obligations apart from the commitment of never leaving the Sky Towers.
But let's get to business. First of all, I need you to know a bit about the background of the project I'm asking you to work on. That will be funnier if we proceed à rebours. What do you know about the Norman view of the Cosmos?"
"As we do, you trust that our world is a mechanism crafted by a Creator, a Magister Horologiorum. Like us, you got that conviction from the Greeks. But, contrarily to us, you don't believe that the Mechanism is perfect. Before reverting to the religion of our Fathers, we took the best from Aristotheles and the Bible. You followed the path of Epicurus and the Gnostics, and mixed their views with the heathen idea that one day the Sky will be falling on your head. You believe the Machanism is faulty, and your priests' main task is to keep it ticking as it should."
"A good resumé, my compliments. Of course, you've missed the whole point of our worldview. But the ingredients are right. Let me correct your exposition: we don't believe that the Mechanism is faulty. We are sure it is. We have proofs. And you - both Romans, Parthians and Qin - would have them too, weren't you so blinded by your own religious dogmas. Let's talk about the Mantle. What is it? According to Qin, it's the black part of the Yin and Yang, with the moon in it playing the role of the small white dot. According to the Parthians... They estabilished as Truth that it is the shadow cast by Ahrimazd on the material world to make it tainted with Evil. And for you Romans... You actually never gave a damn, did you? As long as it doesn't prevent your Automatons to sail the seas of the Known World, its nature is not your concern. But we know. And we have been knowing for centuries.
The Mantle is the most visible proof that our world is part of the Orrery. And that our Orrery is broken. It's a floating dome made of crystalline Aether, designed by the Horloger to block the light of the Sun. It used to move around the Earth one time per day, guaranteeing a balanced night-day cycle almost everywhere on Earth. But now it does not anymore, because the Rouages that spinned it are broken."
"But we do have night-day cycles! And Qin has got to the Moon just as we did, piercing through your "floating dome". Were it made of crystal, wouldn't it have crashed?"
"Aether crystal. It's immaterial, and it can be travelled through. Our best alchemists claim to be a few years away of creating a small specimen of it. As for night-day cycles... They are not uniform in the present time. In the lands of the Empire, day is consistently longer than night, and it gets longer and longer as you travel to the West. Due West from Hibernia there is the Torrid Zone, where the Sun never sets and the temperature is so high that your ships cannot travel safely - nor humans survive, as far as we know. Most of Qin's territory is always shrouded in the blackest night. And even here in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, we get just a small fraction of daylight, for a few moments a day. That's because of Libration: the wheels are jammed, and they keep on oscillating forward and backward instead of completing a full rotation as they should."
"I hope the role you have in mind for me doesn't envisage my full conversion to this worldview, Eminence."
"No it doesn't. But I must dig a bit deeper into it for you to unerstand the purpose of project Le Départ. I must tell you about the other Orreries."
"Other orreries? Isn't just one, ehr... inventive enough?"
"As for the rest of our model, we have proofs. Evidence. Extra-contextus artifacts, and old inscriptions buried in mountain caverns."
"Extra-contextus artifacts? I thought that you--"
"Had no interest in them? Of course. We don't need to plagiarize their technology as you and Qin do. We have ours. Why should we be satisfied with a technology which will never take ourselves any farther than our Orrery's Moon, when we can design ships capable of travelling out of the Atmosphere, and taking us to other Orreries?
But centuries ago, when my people still inhabited the regions North of your Empire, our warriors found a very interesting artifact, and took it to our priests. It was a bronze model orrery. At first, they thougth it to be Greek. Then they noticed that the inscriptions on it were not in any known language, that the borders between states weren't like the borders their world had ever had, and that the bronze dome guaranteeing night-day cycles perfectly rotated around the inner sphere. It was not our Orrery, but the priests didn't take the matter seriously, back in the day.
Then we moved to Nouveau Grande-Bretagne. We started exploring the neighbourhood. Reports from our envoyés stared coming from all over our new small but gnarled kingdom. In a cavern, right under the mount the locals called Kangchenjunga, an enourmous cave was found, with many rooms and pits. And on the bottom of it, an inscription in the same character set as one found on the Other Orrery. 65336 letters from a 32-letter alphabet. Our Orrery's seed. _La Graine_.
We are part of an experiment, Julius. We live in a miniature universe created by the Horloger for the same purpose that's been animating the Normans since their very first day in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne: science. We cannot know the mind of the Horloger, but we know that we are not alone: other miniature world exist too. Billions, and billions, and billions and billions of Orreries like ours. Probably the Horloger is interested in some statistics of sort. Probably he is running an extremely complex parallel simulation. You Romans have been mislead by your blind optimism: he's not very interest in us. Our Orrery's just one among many more than we can possibly conceive. And it's broken. We've never been able to locate the other Orreries, but with your Hiberian Artifact we finally have a device capable of receiving - and possibly transmitting - signals from other Orreries. We have a Beacon which will guide us to an other Orrery! We must get away, Iulius, or the Sky will eventually fall on our heads!"

card.name: PythagoraSwitch
card.desc:
Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus reaches Londin-dans-les-Montagnes, shows his unmistakable Horologium pendant to the town guards and is immediatelty escorted to the Queen of the Normans. As the confidential information in his possession suggested, her rank is revealed to be just a cerimonial façade: as a matter of fact, she holds no power. Nouveau Grande-Bretagne's form of government is something unconceivable for the rest of the Known World: a mix of hierocracy and technarchy, based on a peculiar, NeoPlatonic-tinged cult of Science and firmly steered by the clever authority of the seventy-fourth Evèque of Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, Remi डम्बर Kirwyn.
After a meticulous and rather embarassing strip-search and short and purely formal audience with the Queen, during which Severus does his best to state his motives as clearly (concerning intentions) and vaguely (concerning information) as possible, he is led to the upper floors of the many-bridged Sky Towers, where he finally meets the Evèque. The two discuss conditions and very restricted information; then consent to the terms of a historical exchange: Severus will submit the Hybernian Artifact and his liberty to the authority of the Evèque, and the Evèque will make him his personal assistant for the ultra-secret _Le Départ_ project, under the new name Pythagoras.

"Circumspectors in Rome have longly been knowing your Queen was a purely cerimonial cover for your technochratic meddlings, but I think nobody, even in Purpura Officium, ever suspected the extent of her uselessness."

"I'm sure you perfectly understand that you're currently in no position to negotiate. And I have no obligation to reward you. I could actually take your precious artifact and have you locked up in jail at any moment."
"But you're not doing that. Why?"
"Because, as I suggested before, I need your skills. Your knowledge of Roman technology, coupled with your dexterity with cover-ups and decit aimed at the Empire's enemies and rivals... and at the Empire itself. I'm offering you a position as my personal assistant. But I'm sure you want to know more about the matter you'll be assisting me with."
"My will doesn't seem to be much important, in this conversation.
- On the contrary! It's all about your will. I won't force you to accept my proposal. The sheer presence of the Hybernian Artifact in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne's territory is already a service great enough to guarantee you full protection, without any obligations apart from the commitment of never leaving the Sky Towers.
But let's get to business. First of all, I need you to know a bit about the background of the project I'm asking you to work on. That will be funnier if we proceed à rebours. What do you know about the Norman view of the Cosmos?"
"As we do, you trust that our world is a mechanism crafted by a Creator, a Magister Horologiorum. Like us, you got that conviction from the Greeks. But, contrarily to us, you don't believe that the Mechanism is perfect. Before reverting to the religion of our Fathers, we took the best from Aristotheles and the Bible. You followed the path of Epicurus and the Gnostics, and mixed their views with the heathen idea that one day the Sky will be falling on your head. You believe the Machanism is faulty, and your priests' main task is to keep it ticking as it should."
"A good resumé, my compliments. Of course, you've missed the whole point of our worldview. But the ingredients are right. Let me correct your exposition: we don't believe that the Mechanism is faulty. We are sure it is. We have proofs. And you - both Romans, Parthians and Qin - would have them too, weren't you so blinded by your own religious dogmas. Let's talk about the Mantle. What is it? According to Qin, it's the black part of the Yin and Yang, with the moon in it playing the role of the small white dot. According to the Parthians... They estabilished as Truth that it is the shadow cast by Ahrimazd on the material world to make it tainted with Evil. And for you Romans... You actually never gave a damn, did you? As long as it doesn't prevent your Automatons to sail the seas of the Known World, its nature is not your concern. But we know. And we have been knowing for centuries.
The Mantle is the most visible proof that our world is part of the Orrery. And that our Orrery is broken. It's a floating dome made of crystalline Aether, designed by the Horloger to block the light of the Sun. It used to move around the Earth one time per day, guaranteeing a balanced night-day cycle almost everywhere on Earth. But now it does not anymore, because the Rouages that spinned it are broken."
"But we do have night-day cycles! And Qin has got to the Moon just as we did, piercing through your "floating dome". Were it made of crystal, wouldn't it have crashed?"
"Aether crystal. It's immaterial, and it can be travelled through. Our best alchemists claim to be a few years away of creating a small specimen of it. As for night-day cycles... They are not uniform in the present time. In the lands of the Empire, day is consistently longer than night, and it gets longer and longer as you travel to the West. Due West from Hibernia there is the Torrid Zone, where the Sun never sets and the temperature is so high that your ships cannot travel safely - nor humans survive, as far as we know. Most of Qin's territory is always shrouded in the blackest night. And even here in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, we get just a small fraction of daylight, for a few moments a day. That's because of Libration: the wheels are jammed, and they keep on oscillating forward and backward instead of completing a full rotation as they should."
"I hope the role you have in mind for me doesn't envisage my full conversion to this worldview, Eminence."
"No it doesn't. But I must dig a bit deeper into it for you to unerstand the purpose of project Le Départ. I must tell you about the other Orreries."
"Other orreries? Isn't just one, ehr... inventive enough?"
"As for the rest of our model, we have proofs. Evidence. Extra-contextus artifacts, and old inscriptions buried in mountain caverns."
"Extra-contextus artifacts? I thought that you--"
"Had no interest in them? Of course. We don't need to plagiarize their technology as you and Qin do. We have ours. Why should we be satisfied with a technology which will never take ourselves any farther than our Orrery's Moon, when we can design ships capable of travelling out of the Atmosphere, and taking us to other Orreries?
But centuries ago, when my people still inhabited the regions North of your Empire, our warriors found a very interesting artifact, and took it to our priests. It was a bronze model orrery. At first, they thougth it to be Greek. Then they noticed that the inscriptions on it were not in any known language, that the borders between states weren't like the borders their world had ever had, and that the bronze dome guaranteeing night-day cycles perfectly rotated around the inner sphere. It was not our Orrery, but the priests didn't take the matter seriously, back in the day.
Then we moved to Nouveau Grande-Bretagne. We started exploring the neighbourhood. Reports from our envoyés stared coming from all over our new small but gnarled kingdom. In a cavern, right under the mount the locals called Kangchenjunga, an enourmous cave was found, with many rooms and pits. And on the bottom of it, an inscription in the same character set as one found on the Other Orrery. 65336 letters from a 32-letter alphabet. Our Orrery's seed. _La Graine_.
We are part of an experiment, Julius. We live in a miniature universe created by the Horloger for the same purpose that's been animating the Normans since their very first day in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne: science. We cannot know the mind of the Horloger, but we know that we are not alone: other miniature world exist too. Billions, and billions, and billions and billions of Orreries like ours. Probably the Horloger is interested in some statistics of sort. Probably he is running an extremely complex parallel simulation. You Romans have been mislead by your blind optimism: he's not very interest in us. Our Orrery's just one among many more than we can possibly conceive. And it's broken. We've never been able to locate the other Orreries, but with your Hiberian Artifact we finally have a device capable of receiving - and possibly transmitting - signals from other Orreries. We have a Beacon which will guide us to an other Orrery! We must get away, Iulius, or the Sky will eventually fall on our heads!"

old.desc:
Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus reaches Londin-dans-les-Montagnes, shows his unmistakable Horologium pendant to the town guards and is immediatelty escorted to the Queen of the Normans. As the confidential information in his possession suggested, her rank is revealed to be just a cerimonial façade: as a matter of fact, she holds no power. Nouveau Grande-Bretagne's form of government is something unconceivable for the rest of the Known World: a mix of hierocracy and technarchy, based on a peculiar, NeoPlatonic-tinged cult of Science and firmly steered by the clever authority of the seventy-fourth Evèque of Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, Remi डम्बर Kirwyn.
After a meticulous and rather embarassing strip-search and short and purely formal audience with the Queen, during which Severus does his best to state his motives as clearly (concerning intentions) and vaguely (concerning information) as possible, he is led to the upper floors of the many-bridged Sky Towers, where he finally meets the Evèque. The two discuss conditions and very restricted information; then consent to the terms of a historical exchange: Severus will submit the Hybernian Artifact and his liberty to the authority of the Evèque, and the Evèque will make him his personal assistant for the ultra-secret _Le Départ_ project, under the new name Pythagoras.

"So young, yet so perfect for her role! "Circumspectors in Rome have longly been knowing your Queen was a purely cerimonial cover for your technochratic meddlings, but I think nobody, even in Purpura Officium, ever suspected the extent of her uselessness."
"Your masters in Rome never suspected of many important matters as far as I know. Starting with your willingness to betray them."
"Throwing authorities off the scent is my most obvious skill. I didn't succeed with your men just because I didn't even try."

I'm offering you a position as my personal assistant. But I'm sure you want to know more about the matter you'll be assisting me with."
"My will doesn't seem to be much important, in this conversation.
- On the contrary! It's all about your will. I won't force you to accept my proposal. The sheer presence of the Hybernian Artifact in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne's territory is already a service great enough to guarantee you full protection, without any obligations apart from the commitment of never leaving the Sky Towers.
But let's get to business. First of all, I need you to know a bit about the background of the project I'm asking you to work on. That will be funnier if we proceed à rebours. What do you know about the Norman view of the Cosmos?"
"As we do, you trust that our world is a mechanism crafted by a Creator, a Magister Horologiorum. Like us, you got that conviction from the Greeks. But, contrarily to us, you don't believe that the Mechanism is perfect. Before reverting to the religion of our Fathers, we took the best from Aristotheles and the Bible. You followed the path of Epicurus and the Gnostics, and mixed their views with the heathen idea that one day the Sky will be falling on your head. You believe the Machanism is faulty, and your priests' main task is to keep it ticking as it should."
"A good resumé, my compliments. Of course, you've missed the whole point of our worldview. But the ingredients are right. Let me correct your exposition: we don't believe that the Mechanism is faulty. We are sure it is. We have proofs. And you - both Romans, Parthians and Qin - would have them too, weren't you so blinded by your own religious dogmas. Let's talk about the Mantle. What is it? According to Qin, it's the black part of the Yin and Yang, with the moon in it playing the role of the small white dot. According to the Parthians... They estabilished as Truth that it is the shadow cast by Ahrimazd on the material world to make it tainted with Evil. And for you Romans... You actually never gave a damn, did you? As long as it doesn't prevent your Automatons to sail the seas of the Known World, its nature is not your concern. But we know. And we have been knowing for centuries.
The Mantle is the most visible proof that our world is part of the Orrery. And that our Orrery is broken. It's a floating dome made of crystalline Aether, designed by the Horloger to block the light of the Sun. It used to move around the Earth one time per day, guaranteeing a balanced night-day cycle almost everywhere on Earth. But now it does not anymore, because the Rouages that spinned it are broken."
"But we do have night-day cycles! And Qin has got to the Moon just as we did, piercing through your "floating dome". Were it made of crystal, wouldn't it have crashed?"
"Aether crystal. It's immaterial, and it can be travelled through. Our best alchemists claim to be a few years away of creating a small specimen of it. As for night-day cycles... They are not uniform in the present time. In the lands of the Empire, day is consistently longer than night, and it gets longer and longer as you travel to the West. Due West from Hibernia there is the Torrid Zone, where the Sun never sets and the temperature is so high that your ships cannot travel safely - nor humans survive, as far as we know. Most of Qin's territory is always shrouded in the blackest night. And even here in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, we get just a small fraction of daylight, for a few moments a day. That's because of Libration: the wheels are jammed, and they keep on oscillating forward and backward instead of completing a full rotation as they should."
"I hope the role you have in mind for me doesn't envisage my full conversion to this worldview, Eminence."
"No it doesn't. But I must dig a bit deeper into it for you to unerstand the purpose of project Le Départ. I must tell you about the other Orreries."
"Other orreries? Isn't just one, ehr... inventive enough?"
"As for the rest of our model, we have proofs. Evidence. Extra-contextus artifacts, and old inscriptions buried in mountain caverns."
"Extra-contextus artifacts? I thought that you--"
"Had no interest in them? Of course. We don't need to plagiarize their technology as you and Qin do. We have ours. Why should we be satisfied with a technology which will never take ourselves any farther than our Orrery's Moon, when we can design ships capable of travelling out of the Atmosphere, and taking us to other Orreries?
But centuries ago, when my people still inhabited the regions North of your Empire, our warriors found a very interesting artifact, and took it to our priests. It was a bronze model orrery. At first, they thougth it to be Greek. Then they noticed that the inscriptions on it were not in any known language, that the borders between states weren't like the borders their world had ever had, and that the bronze dome guaranteeing night-day cycles perfectly rotated around the inner sphere. It was not our Orrery, but the priests didn't take the matter seriously, back in the day.
Then we moved to Nouveau Grande-Bretagne. We started exploring the neighbourhood. Reports from our envoyés stared coming from all over our new small but gnarled kingdom. In a cavern, right under the mount the locals called Kangchenjunga, an enourmous cave was found, with many rooms and pits. And on the bottom of it, an inscription in the same character set as one found on the Other Orrery. 65336 letters from a 32-letter alphabet. Our Orrery's seed. _La Graine_.
We are part of an experiment, Julius. We live in a miniature universe created by the Horloger for the same purpose that's been animating the Normans since their very first day in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne: science. We cannot know the mind of the Horloger, but we know that we are not alone: other miniature world exist too. Billions, and billions, and billions and billions of Orreries like ours. Probably the Horloger is interested in some statistics of sort. Probably he is running an extremely complex parallel simulation. You Romans have been mislead by your blind optimism: he's not very interest in us. Our Orrery's just one among many more than we can possibly conceive. And it's broken. We've never been able to locate the other Orreries, but with your Hiberian Artifact we finally have a device capable of receiving - and possibly transmitting - signals from other Orreries. We have a Beacon which will guide us to an other Orrery! We must get away, Iulius, or the Sky will eventually fall on our heads!"

card.name: PythagoraSwitch
card.desc:
Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus reaches Londin-dans-les-Montagnes, shows his unmistakable Horologium pendant to the town guards and is immediatelty escorted to the Queen of the Normans. As the confidential information in his possession suggested, her rank is revealed to be just a cerimonial façade: as a matter of fact, she holds no power. Nouveau Grande-Bretagne's form of government is something unconceivable for the rest of the Known World: a mix of hierocracy and technarchy, based on a peculiar, NeoPlatonic-tinged cult of Science and firmly steered by the clever authority of the seventy-fourth Evèque of Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, Remi डम्बर Kirwyn.
After a meticulous and rather embarassing strip-search and short and purely formal audience with the Queen, during which Severus does his best to state his motives as clearly (concerning intentions) and vaguely (concerning information) as possible, he is led to the upper floors of the many-bridged Sky Towers, where he finally meets the Evèque. The two discuss conditions and very restricted information; then consent to the terms of a historical exchange: Severus will submit the Hybernian Artifact and his liberty to the authority of the Evèque, and the Evèque will make him his personal assistant for the ultra-secret _Le Départ_ project, under the new name Pythagoras.

"Throwing authorities off the scent is my most obvious skill. I didn't succeed with your men just because I didn't even try."

But let's get to business. First of all, I need you to know a bit about the background of the project I'm asking you to work on. That will be funnier if we proceed à rebours. What do you know about the Norman view of the Cosmos?
- As we do, you trust that our world is a mechanism crafted by a Creator, a Magister Horologiorum. Like us, you got that conviction from the Greeks. But, contrarily to us, you don't believe that the Mechanism is perfect. Before reverting to the religion of our Fathers, we took the best from Aristotheles and the Bible. You followed the path of Epicurus and the Gnostics, and mixed their views with the heathen idea that one day the Sky will be falling on your head. You believe the Machanism is faulty, and your priests' main task is to keep it ticking as it should.
- A good resumé, my compliments. Of course, you've missed the whole point of our worldview. But the ingredients are right. Let me correct your exposition: we don't believe that the Mechanism is faulty. We are sure it is. We have proofs. And you - both Romans, Parthians and Qin - would have them too, weren't you so blinded by your own religious dogmas. Let's talk about the Mantle. What is it? According to Qin, it's the black part of the Yin and Yang, with the moon in it playing the role of the small white dot. According to the Parthians... They estabilished as Truth that it is the shadow cast by Ahrimazd on the material world to make it tainted with Evil. And for you Romans... You actually never gave a damn, did you? As long as it doesn't prevent your Automatons to sail the seas of the Known World, its nature is not your concern. But we know. And we have been knowing for centuries.
The Mantle is the most visible proof that our world is part of the Orrery. And that our Orrery is broken. It's a floating dome made of crystalline Aether, designed by the Horloger to block the light of the Sun. It used to move around the Earth one time per day, guaranteeing a balanced night-day cycle almost everywhere on Earth. But now it does not anymore, because the Rouages that spinned it are broken.
- But we still have night-day cycles! And Qin has got to the Moon just as we did, piercing through your "floating dome". Were it made of crystal, wouldn't it have crashed?
- Aether crystal. It's immaterial, and it can be travelled through. Our best alchemists claim to be a few years away of creating a small specimen of it. As for night-day cycles... They are not uniform in the present time. In the lands of the Empire, day is consistently longer than night, and it gets longer and longer as you travel to the West. Due West from Hibernia there is the Torrid Zone, where the Sun never sets and the temperature is so high that your ships cannot travel safely - nor humans survive, as far as we know. Most of Qin's territory is always shrouded in the blackest night. And even here in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, we get just a small fraction of daylight, for a few moments a day. That's because of Libration: the wheels are jammed, and they keep on oscillating forward and backward instead of completing a full rotation as they should.
- I hope the role you have in mind for me doesn't envisage my full conversion to this worldview, Eminence.
- No it doesn't. But I must dig a bit deeper into it for you to unerstand the purpose of project Le Départ. I must tell you about the other Orreries.
- Other orreries? Isn't just one, ehr... inventive enough?
- As for the rest of our model, we have proofs. Evidence. Extra-contextus artifacts, and old inscriptions buried in mountain caverns.
- Extra-contextus artifacts? I thought that you--
- Had no interest in them? Of course. We don't need to plagiarize their technology as you and Qin do. We have ours. Why should we be satisfied with a technology which will never take ourselves any farther than our Orrery's Moon, when we can design ships capable of travelling out of the Atmosphere, and taking us to other Orreries?
But centuries ago, when my people still inhabited the regions North of your Empire, our warriors found a very interesting artifact, and took it to our priests. It was a bronze model orrery. At first, they thougth it to be Greek. Then they noticed that the inscriptions on it were not in any known language, that the borders between states weren't like the borders their world had ever had, and that the bronze dome guaranteeing night-day cycles perfectly rotated around the inner sphere. It was not our Orrery, but the priests didn't take the matter seriously, back in the day.
Then we moved to Nouveau Grande-Bretagne. We started exploring the neighbourhood. Reports from our envoyés stared coming from all over our new small but gnarled kingdom. In a cavern, right under the mount the locals called Kangchenjunga, an enourmous cave was found, with many rooms and pits. And on the bottom of it, an inscription in the same character set as one found on the Other Orrery. 65336 letters from a 32-letter alphabet. Our Orrery's seed. _La Graine_.
We are part of an experiment, Julius. We live in a miniature universe created by the Horloger for the same purpose that's been animating the Normans since their very first day in Nouveau Grande-Bretagne: science. We cannot know the mind of the Horloger, but we know that we are not alone: other miniature world exist too. Billions, and billions, and billions and billions of Orreries like ours. Probably the Horloger is interested in some statistics of sort. Probably he is running an extremely complex parallel simulation. You Romans have been mislead by your blind optimism: he's not very interest in us. Our Orrery's just one among many more than we can possibly conceive. And it's broken. We've never been able to locate the other Orreries, but with your Hiberian Artifact we finally have a device capable of receiving - and possibly transmitting - signals from other Orreries. We have a Beacon which will guide us to an other Orrery! We must get away, Iulius, or the Sky will eventually fall on our heads!

old.desc:
Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus reaches Londin-dans-les-Montagnes, shows his unmistakable Horologium pendant to the town guards and is immediatelty escorted to the Queen of the Normans. As the confidential information in his possession suggested, her rank is revealed to be just a cerimonial façade: as a matter of fact, she holds no power. Nouveau Grande-Bretagne's form of government is something unconceivable for the rest of the Known World: a mix of hierocracy and technarchy, based on a peculiar, NeoPlatonic-tinged cult of Science and firmly steered by the clever authority of the seventy-fourth Evèque of Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, Remi डम्बर Kirwyn.
After a meticulous and rather embarassing strip-search and short and purely formal audience with the Queen, during which Severus does his best to state his motives as clearly (concerning intentions) and vaguely (concerning information) as possible, he is led to the upper floors of the many-bridged Sky Towers, where he finally meets the Evèque. The two discuss conditions and very restricted information; then consent to the terms of a historical exchange: Severus will submit the Hybernian Artifact and his liberty to the authority of the Evèque, and the Evèque will make him his personal assistant for the ultra-secret _Le Départ_ project, under the new name Pythagoras.

## Screwy Cogs (_Darjk_)

**Question**: _How does project _Le Départ_ relate to the Normans' belief system?_
**Stage**: _The Hall of the Evèque in the Sky Towers of Londin-dans-les-Montagnes_
**Characters**: _Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus (Pythagoras), Remi डम्बर Kirwyn, seventy-fourth Evèque of Nouveau Grande-Bretagne._

**Answer**:

_[Excerpt from the conversation between Remi डम्बर Kirwyn and Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus]

- I gather that the Queen was not a problem - Said the dark-skinned Remi, shrouded in his crimson robe.
- Not at all, Eminence. She seemed pleased with my patchy report. - Answered Iulius.
- So young, yet so perfect for her role! She's the most impeccably brainless monarch in the last six or seven decades - brainlessness being of course the most important quality for a Norman Monarch besides regal appearance... and the main reason why so many of the last monarchs have been, in fact, monarch_esses_
- Circumspectors in Rome have longly been knowing your Queen was a purely cerimonial cover for your technochratic meddlings, but I think nobody, even in Purpura Officium, ever suspected the extent of her uselessness.
- Your masters in Rome never suspected of many important matters as far as I know. Starting with your willingness to betray them.
- Throwing authorities off the scent is my most obvious skill. I didn't succeed with your men just because I didn't even try.
- Don't overestimate your gift for divertion, Iulius. But don't underestimate it, too. It's precisely for that gift that I arranged things to get you here, as you may have guessed.
- Your men have been quite explicit about that since the first fortuitous meeting we had in Sirmium. And about your interest in the Hybernian Artifact. But their clearness about your motives was frankly much less remarkable. You Normans have never been interested in extra-continuum technology: why starting now? And why trying to get to me? I'm not silly enough to buy the flimflam you instructed them to throw at me.  Yet I'm here: what do you really want of me? And what do you offer?
- I'm sure you perfectly know that you're currently in no position to negotiate. And I have no obligation to reward you. I could actually take your precious artifact and have you locked up in jail at any moment.
- But you're not doing that. Why?
- Because, as I suggested before, I need your skills. Your knowledge of Roman technology, coupled with your dexterity with cover-ups and decit aimed at the Empire's enemies and rivals... and at the Empire itself. I'm offering you a position as my personal assistant. But I'm sure you want to know more about the matter you'll be assisting me with.

The two discuss conditions and very restricted information; then consent to the terms of a historical exchange: Severus will submit the Hybernian Artifact and his liberty to the authority of the Evèque, and the Evèque will make him his personal assistant for the ultra-secret _Le Départ_ project, under the new name Pythagoras.

card.name: Legacy
card.desc: - ## Marco Sgrignoli @wago - Project _Le Départ_

old.desc: - ## Marco Sgrignoli @wago - Undefined

card.name: Of branches and twigs
card.desc:
An alarming, hand-written note is found next to the dead body of Theron of Syracuse.

The senior and well-respected researcher working on the Hybernian Artefact says he may have discovered that the interdimensional navigation technique can not only be used to navigate through parallel dimensions, but also to branch from the current one into an almost identical one from the starting point. The only caveat would be that the navigators die in their current branch, and carry on into the new one.

Theron writes that he believes that the branches would be free of the adverse effects of interdimensional travel in their respective trunks, thus providing a chance at a fresh start from everyone. He writes that he has no way of proving this but by trying this himself.

Theron is never heard of again, but the promise of a fresh start, albeit faint, leads a number of his colleagues to organise an escape plan from a terrible past plagued by bad choices.

card.name: PythagoraSwitch
card.desc:
Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus reaches Londin-dans-les-Montagnes, shows his unmistakable Horologium pendant to the town guards and is immediatelty escorted to the Queen of the Normans. As the confidential information in his possession suggested, her rank is revealed to be just a cerimonial façade: as a matter of fact, she holds no power. Nouveau Grande-Bretagne's form of government is something unconceivable for the rest of the Known World: a mix of hierocracy and technarchy, based on a peculiar, NeoPlatonic-tinged cult of Science and firmly steered by the clever authority of the seventy-fourth Evèque of Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, Remi डम्बर Kirwyn.
After a meticulous and rather embarassing strip-search and short and purely formal audience with the Queen, during which Severus does his best to state his motives as clearly (concerning intentions) and vaguely (concerning information) as possible, he is led to the upper floors of the many-bridged Sky Towers, where he finally meets the Evèque. The two discuss conditions and very restricted information; then consent to the terms of a historical exchange: Severus will submit the Hybernian Artifact and his liberty to the authority of the Evèque, and the Evèque will make him his personal assistant for the ultra-secret _Le Départ_ project, under the new name Pythagoras.

card.name: Across the Seas
card.desc:
After hiding for months aboard the Septiremis Mechanica Caesarea Martis Basiscostrivantus, flagship to the Purpura Officium of the Factores Horologiorum, under the assumed name of Vanitus Vantus Tartessostrovantus, Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus is forced to abandon his disguise of maritime servitude to the Purpura Officium in the deepest hours of the darkest moonless night as the fleet led by the Septiremis is on final approach to the island of Taproban.

The Purpura Officium is the highest and most secret branch of the Factores Horologiorum, operating in shadows across the Empire and its Tributaries, Vassals, Colonies, Administered Territories and Allies and tasked with the most sensitive research into mechanical and alchemical innovations. The Officium's interest in Taproban is what brought Iulius aboard, for a chance of reaching east far past Mesopotamia to the mountains of Nouveau Grande-Bretagne while avoiding the Parthian Confederation, impossible to be trusted for a Metallicus unconstrained by its Necessitates.

He is carrying the Hybernian artifact inside his brass chestplates. After powering through the waters to the mainland coast, he resumes his objectives: go where the highest mountains in the world seem to touch the heavens, past the 5800 leagues long and 100 feet tall wall surrounding the displaced territories of Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, discover what it means to be free of the Necessitates among the ancestral enemies of the Empire and their mechanical creations, to find the Queen of the Normans in Sky Towers of Londin-dans-les-Montagnes and give to her chemists and scientists the artifact that could very well change the tide of their doomed resistance.

card.name: Having acquired redacted information about the so-called Apollo Event, where 5 Roman agents died under strange circumstances, and the real reason behind it, the Qin Conglomerate orders a strike on Londin-dans-les-Montagnes to retrieve the part of the Hybernian Artefact in the hands of Queen Louarn of Normans – which the Qin Strategist mistake for the complete Artefact. The attack is unsuccessful and triggers a war declaration from the Norman-Breton Commonwealth and its Roman ally. The Roman Emperor, taking advantage of the chaos in the Londin region due to the raging war, authorizes a secret Scunkii operation to retrieve the last part of the Hybernian Artefact. The Scunkii succeeds and the missing part is sent to the Extracontextus Center in Patavium, allowing for the correct operation of the Hybernian Artefact. In Patavium, the Extracontextus Magistri discover that by generating a copy the Gaussian field signal transmitted by the Artefact and transmitting it with a certain phase, the Artefact "creates" every 24 hours a small black sphere infused with immense energy.

old.name: Having acquired redacted information about the so-called Apollo Event, where 5 Roman agents died under strange circumstances, and the real reason behind it, the Qin Conglomerate orders a quick and concentrated attack on Londin-dans-les-Montagnes to retrieve the part of the Hybernian Artefact in the hands of Queen Louarn of Normans – which the Qin Strategist mistake for the complete Artefact. Desperate Attempt
card.desc:
A group of CYPLEUM officials employed at the site discuss the opportunity of sending a team to retrieve the Hybernian Artifact, even knowing that it would be missing the interdimensional fragment, held at the time by the Queen of the Normans; the agent-scientist that used the Necant artifact, H-Duilius, can not determine alone if the fragment is necessary.

H-Duilius argues that there is a small possibility that the "APOLLO 1" patch, an artifact discovered in the hands of two local children, could be used to harness a small quantity of interdimensional energy, since it came from the same breach.

Though unconvinced, the officials dispatch a small team to Beneventum, where they succesfully manage to retrieve the Hybernian Artifact, not without some resistance from the Norman druids.

The APOLLO patch actually manages to influence the artifact's operation, but for a fraction of a second, in which five agents are sucked in the portal. A surviving agent swears in his official report to have seen through the portal a grey landscape, a black sky, and beyond that, the World.

A group of CYPLEUM officials employed at the site discuss the opportunity of sending a team to retrieve the Hybernian artifact, even knowing that it would be missing the interdimensional fragment, held at the time by the Queen of the Normans; the agent-scientist that used the Necant artifact, H-Duilius, can not determine alone if the fragment is necessary.

H-Duilius argues that the "APOLLO 1" patch, an artifact discoveres in the hands of two local children, there is a small possibility of harnessing a small quantity of interdimensional energy from this artifact, since it came from the same breach.

Though unconvinced, the officials dispatch a small team to Beneventum, where they succesfully manage to retrieve the Hybernian Artifact, not without some resistance from the Norman druids.

The APOLLO patch actually manages to influence the artifact's operation, but for a fraction of a second, in which five agents are sucked in the portal. A surviving agent swears in his official report to have seen through the portal a grey landscape, a black sky, and beyond that, the World.

## Nectant artefact
Ancient vest of Persian origins able to preserve whatever stored inside by altering the matter outside of it, thus creating a barrier of timeless and stable environment.

card.name: Artefacts
card.desc: ## Nectant artefact

card.name: A piece of cake
card.desc: General Vinsorius has returned home following the conclusion of the first part of his mission. Data recorded from the artefact appear to be harder than expected to be deciphered, while additional security measures have to be taken to prevent the Scunkii squad to interfere again with the operation. One evening, while he is sitting at his desk, looking at sheets of paper filled with numbers in an attempt to figure out himself the meaning of those recordings extrapolated from the artefact's field, his young nephew peeks over his shoulder and asks him the meaning of all those foreign words. The research squad is immediately allerted.

card.name: Beyond The Veil
card.desc:
The Nectant artefact was an ancient vest of Persian origins able to preserve whatever stored inside by altering the matter outside of it, thus creating a barrier of timeless and stable environment. 
After being given the order to find the truth about what happened at the site whatever the cost, a team of secret agent, the Agents of CYPLEUM, decided to employ the Necant. One man entered the site to retrieve all information needed, and after two days he returned to the nearby domum fidelem affirming that he now knew how to create a stable portal and that he needed the Hybernian artefact to do that.

card.name: The Fox and the Hound
card.desc: After the destruction and mayhem caused by the Hybernian Artefact in Noveau Grande-Bretagne, the legions arrive to guarantee that Londin-dans-les-Montagnes will not be invaded by the Parthian Confederation, and the artifact lost to the Empire’s mightiest rival. A deal is struck between old enemies: the artefact will be brought to Beneventum, where a team of Norman druids will take part in the investigation along with Gaulish druids and Imperial Docti of the Prometheus group. In exchange, the Roman legions will stay in Londin to defend the city, along with a few mercenaries paid by the Norman-Breton Commonwealth. To ensure the Romans will not take over, Queen Louarn of Normans, de facto ruler of the Commonwealth, retains an important part of the Artefact that is necessary to use it for interdimensional travel purposes.

card.name: Across the Seas
card.desc:
After hiding for months aboard the Septiremis Mechanica Caesarea Martis Basiscostrivantus, flagship to the Purpura Officium of the Factores Horologiorum, under the assumed name of Vanitus Vantus Tartessostrovantus, Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus is forced to abandon his disguise of maritime servitude to the Purpura Officium in the deepest hours of the darkest moonless night as the fleet led by the Septiremis is on final approach to the island of Taproban.

The Purpura Officium is the highest and most secret branch of the Factores Horologiorum, operating in shadows across the Empire and its Tributaries, Vassals, Colonies, Administered Territories and Allies and tasked with the most sensitive research into mechanical and alchemical innovations. The Officium's interest in Taproban is what brought Iulius aboard, for a chance of reaching east far past Mesopotamia to the mountains of Nouveau Grande-Bretagne while avoiding the Parthian Confederation, impossible to be trusted for a Metallicus unconstrained by its Necessitates.

He is carrying the Hybernian artifact inside his brass chestplates. After powering through the waters to the mainland coast, he resumes his objectives: go where the highest mountains in the world seem to touch the heavens, past the 5800 leagues long and 100 feet tall wall surrounding the displaced territories of Nouveau Grande-Bretagne, discover what it means to be free of the Necessitates among the ancestral enemies of the Empire and their mechanical creations, to find the Queen of the Normans in Sky Towers of Londin-dans-les-Montagnes and give to her chemists and scientists the artifact that could very well change the tide of their doomed resistance.

card.name: Overthrow Allowance
card.desc: Activates next turn

card.name: The Truth
card.desc:
The first Parthian expedition to explore Taproban found a series of deeply unusual objects of seemingly unfathomable function and absurd craftsmanship. 
After further inquiry, a meeting was called to establish the final truth on these objects. The Kaveh Secretary of Materials, the Esfandyiar Secretary of Religion, and the Suren Ministry of External Affairs and Esptionage all agreed, based on their investigation, that the objects could be traced back to the Ordo Mundorum, a secret cult based in the Eastern Roman Empire and dedicated to destabilising reality by introducing extraneous objects. After a short debate everyone else, including the influential Mihran Ministry of War, agreed to the conclusion and the Definitive Truth on the Taprobanean Objects was proclaimed by the Zoroaster Ministry of Truth and Flame. Evidence of a Roman investigation into the objects were consequently attributed to the Empire’s ongoing war on secret religions, and given limited attention. 
Thanks to the Empire’s masterful craftsmen, spies, and diplomats, the Roman plan had succeeded.

card.name: A Message for You
card.desc:
General Gulielmus Vinsorius is summoned by the lead investigator in charge of studying the Hybernian artefact only to be told that the research is at a standstill. The General is understandably upset at the news, but keeps his Hybernian aplomb and inquires as to whether anything can be done in order to overcome the situation. The lead investigator explains that the artefact appears to proactively counteract any attempt at analysis other than measuring the gaussian field it emits, and visually inspecting its surface. Anything else, from plain old hammer and chisel to Chi-rays have failed. The General leaves, reassuring the scientist that he will think of something.

Come night-time, a thin, tall figure breaks into the laboratorium and leaves a bloodied note on the scientist's table, signed by the Scunkii. The next day, the General is informed that the gaussian field emitted by the artefact is probably transmitting a message, and efforts are underway to record and decipher it.

card.name: Mors Parabolica
card.desc:
The first case of mors parabolica involved Archius, the scientist appointed to data sorting. He was found dead in his laboratorium, his upper arts reassembled in an arrow sing departing from each side of the torso and piercing through his head, the hands coming out from the back of the skull. Shortly after followed the data handlers, Martia and Hippocus, the first suffocated from the absence of mouth and nose, the other bent in half backwards, with his cervical vertebrae broken. Three days after the breaching, all people who partook in the experiment were reported dead. 

A team of physicians was appointed to the investigation, but after a week they were all found victim of the same type of demise. Afraid the morbus would break out, no other person was let near the site, and the people who did were confined inside the site’s basement to die. Only the findings of the physicians survived the events. All the deaths were found to have one thing in common: the DNA of the deceased had been triggered by the viral morbus to modify itself. In one note, one physician had hypothesised the very change in the DNA was a type of communication itself, the language from the other dimension.

card.name: Luna is divided in three territories. The largest one is occupied by the Roman Empire, the first nation to set foot on the Moon, another one is occupied by Qin, and the smallest is actually a collection of territories belonging to Roman Tributaries. The Qin bases on Luna are considered critical for assessing the mainland, which is almost entirely covered by the Mantle, and to protect a delicate balance that grants the Empire's current supremacy in the cis-lunar space. When an Extracontextus Artifact is identified in Qin Lunar Territory, the Empire know they must act very carefully and in total secrecy to recover it, lest they provoke an enemy they just do not know enough about. A heated debate about strategic priorities is interrupted when the Emperor himself gives the go-ahead. The operation, carefully planned, is a success, but Qin is awakened to the presence, and potential, of the artifacts.

card.desc: Not far from the breach site lived two young siblings, Marcus and Aquilina. Days after the experiment they are sent by their father Camillus to hunt a wild goat to be offered in sacrifice to the god Apollo. While in the fields, Aquilina spots a small piece of textile, with a drawing sewn in bright colors that she had never seen before. The patch depicts a map and a strange object, and bears the name of the god itself, together with three unknown words: WHITE, GRISSOM and CHAFFEE.

card.name: The steel production of the Arzebia Inferior region, core of the Roman heavy industry, faces a sudden and steep collapse, bringing the Empire on the brink of a dangerous economic crisis. To avoid a catastrophic chain effect and to understand the reason behind the production drop, the Senate orders an official inquiry while the Augustus imposes the special law on the region, appointing himself as the official Legatus and deposing the current, Senate-appointed Legatus. The scarce information released to the public by the long-lasting inquiry, along with the centralization of power pushed forward by the Augustus, cause widespread discontent giving rise and increasing political power to extremist movements. On the other hand, economic crisis spreads and ultimately puts the Empire in a disadvantaged economic position with the respect to the Parthian Confederation. Nonetheless, the inquiry reveals an important news, which is labelled as secret by the Senate: two Extracontextus artifacts have caused the Arzebia crisis, and they have both been secured by the Empire, which plans to use them at his advantage against the Parthians.

A team of roman scientists and gaulish druids makes the first attempt to open a dimensional breach. The result is not stable and eventually collapses, but last long enough to let researchers gather a huge quantity of data. Shortly after, all the involved people start dying in misterious circumstances. While the  Senate negates any involvement in this matter, the Emperor entrusts a small group of secret agents to find out what is happening and allows the use of the Necant artifact for that purpose.
Is This Silence?
card.desc: A few hours after departing from Portus Itius near Gesoriacum, the massive sentient cruise-ship Varinia Maris Romanostrivantus is caught in an Atlantic storm and all the Mechanicals on board are compelled into Maritime Safety Regulation duties. The mechanical servitor leased to the influential patrician family of the Severii is struck by falling coffers in one of the luxury rooms on the upper decks of the ship and its alchemical bondage rune is scratched. The slave Iulius Severus Severiustrivantus rouses from the incident without the burning pain searing throughout his mind and body as the youngest son of the Severii orders him to gather the fallen debris, secure the family rooms and the invaluable "Hybernian" artifact the family Notarius has entrusted to the young Praefectus to aide him in his duties across Caledonia. Iulius carries out the commands as if nothing had happened.

card.name: Difficult negotiations take place in the neutral Costantinopolis between the Empire and their best allies and rivals, the Parthian Confederation. The issue concerns the status of the newly discovered - but long-fabled - island of Taproban, Southeast of the Parthian-suzerain Ινδικό βασίλειο. While the Romans claim the land by virtue of "Cuius legio, eius regio" (the island was allegedly first visited by the crew of a Roman military liburna mechanica on their way to the Medium Regnum), the Parthians hold that the island is theirs because its close to the coast of the Basileio and the first accounts of it date back to Greek sources. As a matter of fact, the Romans are interested in the island because they believe it's home to a very ancient Extracontextus artifact, and are secretly sending speculatoria navigia and circumspectores to explore it and secure its strategic areas. The negotiations fail, but the secret mission proves to be a success beyond expectations.

Scunkii
card.desc: The self-named Scunkii, a band of highly skilled former legionnaires, were recently dishonourably discharged, which is how the Roman Empire recruits black ops operatives of exceptional prowess. Their first mission is to retrieve an artefact believed to be in possession of the Severii, and deliver it in the hands of General Gulielmus Vinsorius. The mission is a success, but the Scunkii feel strangely drawn to the artefact, and resent delivering it to the General.
